PLUME: These lifeforms, mostly composed of water, appear to dwell under the flowing current of the planet, idly diving deeper into the electric core of the planet from time to time - where they presumably feed and rest.
3
2
THATCH: However, on our first expedition to this planet, we were greeted by the sight of these lifeforms <color=orange>on the surface of the ocean!</color> We have never thus far observed this elusive phenomenon again.
4 3
MELORAE: From our short time studying the live specimens that day, they did not appear to possess wisdom to motivate curiosity nor fear. Until we find a way to bypass the ocean current, I am unsure we can learn more about this behavior.
5 1
COLEUS: The presence of specimens frozen in this glacier suggests this species was not native to this planet, but were rather preserved and ejected within a glacier, from the planet destroyed by <color=lightblue>Dark Bramble.</color>
6 5
MELORAE: We suspect the live specimens' terrifying bioelectricity (and natural immunity to electricity) likely was an evolution of self-defense against predators on their home planet, rather than an adaptation to this ocean planet.

COLEUS: Friends, a cyclone approaches! I fear this island does not provide a stable environment for prolonged research; The island appears to be <color=orange>capsizing</color> from the waves due to its lighter mass!

PLUME: Return to the shuttle at once, friends! We have learnt what we can from these perished specimens. When we are able to meet with a live specimen again, we will be able to better study them and record our findings within the <color=orange>new settlement!</color>
